quoteFirst: "Half-past what?  Here, I'm getting mixed.  Why is it
quoteLast: ? What has the clock been gaining like that for?  Here, Syd, why don't you answer, sir?  I can't remember.  What does it all mean?"

quoteFirst: On the fourth day, which must be our last in Longeetoto, we found that the herd had shifted to fresh cover three miles along the base of the mountains. We had no faith in those buffaloes, but about
quoteLast: we sallied forth dutifully and took position on a hill overlooking the new hiding place. This consisted of a wide grove of forest trees varied by occasional open glades and many dense thickets.
title: The Land of Footprints
author: White, Stewart Edward, 1873-1946

quoteFirst: The six members hurried home as soon as school was dismissed. They were to leave at
quoteLast: , and there was still some packing to be done. Mrs. Williamson had set her heart on taking a full Thanksgiving dinner, and there were enough cooking utensils left at the camp, safely packed in strong, dry boxes, to cook it properly. The last thing Mr.
title: The Riddle Club through the holidays
author: Hardy, Alice Dale; Rogers, Walter S. (Walter Stanton), 1870-1937 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Between nine-thirty and ten the prisoners take another turn in the yard, and the second period of work lasts till three in the afternoon. At three is served another allowance of bread, with vegetables or meat according to the day; and from
quoteLast: to four the courtyard echoes again the monotonous tramp of hundreds of pairs of sabots. The last sortie—there are four in all—varies with the seasons; and after supper the prisoners are locked in for the night.
title:
The Dungeons of Old Paris
Being the Story and Romance of the Most Celebrated Prisons of the Monarchy and the Revolution
author: Hopkins, Tighe, 1856-1919

quoteLast: . title: The letters of Queen Victoria, vol. 2, 1844-1853

quoteLast: o'clock exactly, and then I want you to take me upstairs to the clerk's bedroom in the third story, which I suppose is not locked during the daytime?'
title: The Triumphs of Eugène Valmont

quoteFirst: Wicklow promised to put them into the track of the omnibuses running toward Dahlia's abode in the Southwest, and Mary Ann Wicklow, who had a burning desire in her bosom to behold even the outside shell of her friend's new grandeur, undertook very disinterestedly to accompany them. quoteTime: half-past three o'clock in the afternoon

author: Bennett, Arnold, 1867-1931

quoteFirst: Our opinions of Jerusalem at that time are not fit to be recorded here, and they did not change for many a long day. Near Lifta the Turk was making strenuous efforts to keep us out, but by
quoteLast: he was dislodged by a gallant bayonet attack, and Lifta was occupied at dusk. We pushed on to the outskirts of Jerusalem and remained in battle outposts.
title: The History of the Prince of Wales' Civil Service Rifles
author: Anonymous

quoteFirst: He stayed on business at Frenada until
quoteLast: , and then rode full seventeen miles to Rodrigo in two hours to dinner, dressed in all his orders, &c., was in high glee, danced, stayed supper, and at half-past three in the morning went back to Frenada by moonlight, and arrived here before daybreak at six; so that by twelve he was ready again for business, and I saw him amongst others upon a Court-martial on my return at two the next day. Campbell and General O’Lalor managed the fête.
title: The private journal of Judge-Advocate Larpent
author: Larpent, F. Seymour (Francis Seymour), 1776-1845; Larpent, George Gerard de Hochepied, 1786-1855 [Editor]

quoteFirst: On Sunday morning he rose at
quoteLast: , instead of at four, his week-day rising time.  Many of his hard-working customers were astir betimes on Sunday to have the longer holiday.
title: The Fortune Hunter
author: Phillips, David Graham, 1867-1911

quoteFirst: "I asked the official at the door when our train would start, and when he said at
quoteLast: , I said, 'How tiresome!' Rose says the railroads belong to the state here, and that if I find fault with the time-table, it's constructive censure of the Emperor, and that's lese-majesty." She gave way to her mirth, while the boy studied March's face with an appealing smile.
title: Their Silver Wedding Journey — Volume 1
author: Howells, William Dean, 1837-1920

quoteFirst: When more thoroughly known, it is likely that among the numerous coves many more will be found to offer good anchorage; but few are now known, and the distance that can be run during the short winter days is not great. We were told that our halt for the night was to be at Eden Harbour, less than twenty miles south of the English Narrows, and to my great satisfaction we dropped anchor about
quoteLast: , when there was still a full hour of daylight.
title: Notes of a naturalist in South America
author: Ball, John, 1818-1889

quoteLast: or four. Can we get there before then?”

quoteFirst: It was about five o'clock the next morning that, after sitting up reading hard, and trying to recover lost time, till
quoteLast: , North was plunged in a deep sleep, in which he dreamed that Leo was smiling in his eyes, and repeating the words she had uttered in her delirium, when there was a heavy dragging at the night-bell.

quoteLast: , we lost sight of the land; and, from its breaking off so suddenly, conjectured, that what we had seen this day is an island, or, perhaps, a cluster of islands, lying off the main land of Japan; but as the islands, called by Jansen the Schildpads, and by Mr D'Anville Matsima, though laid down nearly in the same situation, are not equal in extent to the land seen by us, we must leave this point undecided.

quoteLast: . Little Charles died about an hour ago, and, as I shall be very busy to-morrow, I came upstairs to ask if you will oblige me by going over to Mrs. Peterson's and remaining with her until the neighbors assemble in the morning. It is an unpleasant duty, and unless you are perfectly willing I will not request you to perform it.
title: Vashti; Or, Until Death Us Do Part
author: Evans, Augusta J. (Augusta Jane), 1835-1909
